Project Objectives and Description: Project Objectives: The objective of the project is to enhance the competitiveness of Indonesian industry, particularly of small and medium industries (SMIs), by: (a) providing public and private technology support services; (b) facilitating the access to public and private technology service providers; (c) strengthening public technology support institutions; and (d) improving the formulation and coordination of industrial technology policies. Project Description: The project would: (a) strengthen Indonesia's system of industrial metrology, standards, testing and quality (MSTQ) support services; (b) support the diffusion of good technology practices through a cost-sharing matching grant fund to finance the competitive provision of technology upgrading services to SMIs by both public and private technology suppliers; (c) provide assistance for reorienting the public research and development labs towards supporting more effective technology development in private industry, especially SMIs; and (d) strengthen the capacity to formulate and coordinate technology and industrial strategies, policies and programs.
 - ii - Project Benefits and Risks: Project Benefits: The Country Assistance Strategy emphasizes the importance of improving Indonesia's competitiveness and the need for a shift toward a productivity based economy and the complimentary private provision of supporting infrastructure services. The proposed project addresses each of these areas through its support for more effective provision of technology services to help improve the competitiveness of Indonesian industry. The package of policy reforms, institutional strengthening and capacity building is expected to help enhance the competitiveness of Indonesia's SMI manufacturing sector, the target group of the project. While the benefits of the actions supported under the project do not lend themselves to precise quantitative analysis, there is ample evidence from the high performing East Asian countries that effective technology support services yield high economic and financial returns for manufacturing companies through reduced product defects, faster manufacturing turnaround times, lower inventories, higher productivity, increased domestic and export sales and new product designs. These benefits are multiples of the cost of the corresponding services and substantially increase the returns on SMIs' existing investments in plant, equipment and human capital. A least-cost approach to project design was taken to increase the effectiveness and utilization of the existing technology service infrastructure primarily through changes in incentives and management practices, accountability, and systems; and restructuring, rather than through investments in additional equipment. The project will lead to increased private provision of technology services and increasing commercialization and result orientation of public industrial technology services, with greater accountability and transparency in public resource use. Project Risks: The reorientation of the public technology infrastructure towards commercial use and result-oriented management, the effective coordination of Government policies for industry and science and technology and the development of competent private service providers may be slower than envisaged. Similarly, the SMI sector may be slow in accessing the new services being offered. To help minimize these risks, project preparation was extended to: (a) help build consensus within government on the need for and ways to achieve this strategic reorientation of public support for technology

INTRODUCTION 1.01 Led by the rapid growth of the manufacturing sector and industrial exports in particular, Indonesia has achieved high rates of growth over the past quarter century, comparable to other high performing East Asian countries. The main source of that growth has been Indonesia's rich natural resources and low-wage labor force. However, the prospects for sustaining rapid growth on that basis are diminishing. International competition in labor-intensive manufacturing is intensifying with trade liberalization in APEC, the global reduction of trade barriers and the emergence of a number of other low- wage competitor countries. The Government of Indonesia (GOI) recognizes that improved productivity, product quality, reliability and delivery will be central to sustaining the country's export drive, overall economic growth and the growth of employment. 1.02 GOI has undertaken a number of measures to achieve these objectives. Continued economic deregulation and trade reform are putting pressure on firms to upgrade their technological capabilities and improve competitiveness. In addition, access to foreign technology to enhance competitiveness has substantially improved as a result of recent efforts to create one of the most liberal foreign direct investment and trade regimes in East Asia. As a complement, Indonesia spends about US$300 million annually on public research and development (R&D) to harness externalities and buttress the limited R&D done by private industry as well as to enhance the limited capacity of the private sector to absorb and adapt imported technology. Indonesia has made substantial investments in the development of scientific and technical manpower in its public technology support institutions (PTSIs) and the Bank has assisted in this effort. 1.03 However, there is a major disconnect between the PTSIs and private industry. Technical support services of the PTSIs are weak as are their marketing efforts to reach out to industry, particularly small and medium industries (SMIs). Experiences of other high performing countries in East Asia and Indonesia's ownl experience in several recent Bank supported projects demonstrate the important contribution technology support services can make to enhance the competitiveness of firms, especially SMIs, in domestic and export markets. But the domestic supply of those services is limited and is predominantly provided by the PTSIs which employ about 80 percent of the country's scarce scientific, technical and engineering manpower. While large firms can easily import those services, there is a market imperfection for SMIs caused by a lack of information about the availability of outside expertise for enhancing their
 -2- competitiveness; their perception that technology services are expensive and poor value for money; and their lack of awareness of the potential gains in competitiveness that could be achieved from using technology support services to adopt best management practices. As a result, demand for those services has been somewhat limited. However, competitive pressures on firms to upgrade their competitiveness through technology upgrading is expected to increase as a result of growing competition in world markets for Indonesia's manufactured products and the country's preannounced plan to significantly reduce import protection over the next few years in the context of GATT and APEC commitments. The proposed project would support measures to reorient Indonesia's public technology support institutions to help meet the growing demands of the private sector, especially SMIs, and encourage the private provision of technology support services to improve competitiveness.
 - 3 - 2. INDUSTRIAL COMPETITIVENESS: THE ROLE OF TECHNOLOGY A. Industrial Sector Background 2.01 The Indonesian economy has achieved consistently high rates of economic growth in the last 25 years--averaging over 6 percent per year which is comparable to other high performing East Asian countries. Per capita income increased more than fifteen-fold to reach US$884 in 1994, and Indonesia has joined the ranks of middle-income countries. Rapid economic growth has been led by the growth of the manufacturing sector which has exceeded 10 percent per year since 1985/86. Manufacturing now accounts for about 21 percent of GDP and has become the largest sector in the economy. 2.02 Reform of economic policies played a major role in stimulating rapid growth of the manufacturing sector. The reform effort was occasioned by the collapse in oil prices in the early 1980s and the consequent prospect of slow economic growth. This led the Government to reassess its economic strategy and embark on an economic reform program in 1986 with the introduction of a series of periodic "deregulation packages" to dismantle the restrictions that had been put in place during the previous period of inward- oriented economic policies. The deregulation process continues today. Maintaining macroeconomic stability through the judicious use of fiscal, monetary and exchange rate policies also remains at the core of the reform program. 2.03 The deregulation process focused on three broad areas: (a) the trade regime, including a reduction in the coverage of NTBs in manufacturing production, a lowering of the tariff ceilings and the number of tariff rates; the provision of free trade status for exporters through the introduction of duty drawback schemes; and reform of the customs administration by transferring customs surveillance for nearly all imports to a reputed private company; (b) the investment regime, including replacing a very complex investment licensing list involving over 7,000 subsectors with a short negative list and gradually reducing the number of activities on the negative list, simplifying investment approval procedures by reducing the number of requirements, providing incentives in the form of duty-free imports of machinery and equipment as well as inputs needed for initial production, and encouraging foreign direct investment by providing the same incentives as those accorded to domestic investors; and (c) the financial sector, including abolishing credit ceilings, eliminating interest rate controls, reducing subsidized directed credits, lowering entry barriers by permitting entry of new banks, including joint ventures with foreign banks, and introducing measures to develop capital markets.' The most recent deregulation packages in 1994-95 removed virtually all barriers to foreign investment, and accelerated trade reform considerably by announcing a significant reduction in the average import tariff and issuing a schedule for future tariff reductions to the year 2003.
 - 4 - 2.04 These stabilization and deregulation efforts generated a very strong response from the private sector, including a boom in private investment and rapid growth in output, non-oil exports, employment and labor productivity. The manufacturing sector has led the recovery of overall GDP, and helped diversify the economy away from its extreme dependence on oil. Growth in manufacturing averaged 12 percent per year from 1986 to 1994, increasing its share in GDP from less than 12 percent to over 20 percent, and almost tripling its absolute size from about US$10 billion to US$28 billion. In contrast to 1980-85, when a large proportion of growth originated from large capital-intensive activities, labor-intensive sectors contributed most of the growth after 1986. Growth in manufacturing employment and labor productivity averaged 7 percent per year, a rate almost double that in the rest of the economy. The manufacturing sector contributed about 30 percent of the growth in both non-oil GDP and total employment. 2.05 There also has been significant structural change in manufacturing in the form of a substantial increase in the outward-orientation of the sector since the mid-1980s. From 1985/86 to 1992/93, manufactured export growth averaged about 30 percent, doubling the sector export-to-output ratio to almost 20 percent. Exports contributed to over 40 percent of manufacturing sector growth during the period, compared to only 13 percent during 1980-1985. The sector contributed about three-fourths of overall non-oil export growth as the share of manufactured exports in total non-oil exports (and total exports) increased from 38 percent (12 percent) to 63 percent (about 50 percent) between 1985/86 and 1994/95. Continued strong manufactured export growth also is considered to be the key determinant of Indonesia's economic performance during the current Sixth Five-Year Development Plan (REPELITA VI), which covers the period 1994/95-1998/99. The Plan has programmed non-oil exports to increase by 17.8 percent per year in dollar terms, compared to 17-9 percent yearly growth realized during REPELITA V. 2.06 Despite impressive recent performance by the manufacturing sector, however, Indonesia's industrial structure exlibits a low level of product diversification and SMI participation compared to other industrializing countries in the region, particularly the more dynanmic NIEs. Almost 80 percent of the recent increase in manufactured exports originated from the country's rich natural resource base--forestry-based wood products and basic metals--and low-wage, labor-intensive activities--textiles, garments and footwear. But Indonesia is being increasingly challenged in international markets by even lower cost producers (e.g., China, India and Vietnam) in labor-intensive products. The need for further industrial diversification was underscored by the relative weakening in the export performance of the main traditional manufactured products--textiles and garments, and plywood--in 1994 although part of the slack was taken up by strong performance of footwear and electronics products, as well as growth in a number of other product categories from a small base. The growth of total manufactured exports in 1994/95 was only 15 percent. compared to rates double that in previous years. In addition, industrial employment and output concentrated in a large number of micro enterprises on one hand and large firms and business conglomerates on the other. The shares of SMIs in total value added and total employment in industry is lower than those in other high performing countries of East Asia (HPEACs).
 - 5 - 2.07 Indonesia has made great strides in opening up its economy. Increasing competition in and globalization of international markets of manufactured products will require further deregulation of the economy. Corresponding action will need to be taken to encourage more effective and better quality service provision to facilitate the adjustment of industry, especially SMIs, to increasing competition and to reap the benefits from it. The challenge for Indonesia is to further diversify its manufactured export base, especially into skilled-labor intensive products, and increase efficiency and value added in its traditional products by cutting costs and moving upmarket through management improvements and technology upgrading particularly of SMIs. B. Science and Technology Strategy and Institutions 2.08 Indonesian firms will need to develop their technological capabilities to improve their competitiveness and take advantage of the opportunities created by trade liberalization within APEC, the reduction of global trade barriers and continued rapid growth of world trade. International competitiveness increasingly requires firms to compete on more than just the basis of factor cost advantages. Product development capabilities, fast delivery, total quality--including the ability to meet customers' rigorous quality standards and obtain ISO 9000 certification--and the ability to respond rapidly to changing customer needs have all become increasingly important determinants of competitive advantage. 2.09 The ability to compete on all these fronts is predicated heavily on the adoption of best-practice technologies. There are two important lessons for Indonesia from the experiences of the other HPEACs in this regard. First, overall economic policies play an important role in promoting the development of technological capabilities for improved competitiveness. Within the framework of sound macroeconomic, trade and competition policies have played a key role in moving industry toward the international best-practice frontier by compelling and enabling firms to lower costs, and improve product quality, delivery and design. Second, even though the HPEACs vary widely with respect to their development strategies, the role accorded to foreign investment and the extent of government intervention, they all implemented specific technology policies to promote the diffusion of technology and help their industrial sectors close the gap vis-a-vis international best practice, recognizing the important externalities and market failures associated with industrial technology development. Effective systems of metrology, standards, testing and quality control (MSTQ), technology extension services and applied R&D have made important contributions to enhancing industrial competitiveness in those countries. 2.10 The focus of Indonesia's technology policies, in contrast, has been on a major push to develop several technology-intensive public sector "strategic industries", which include aircraft manufacturing, shipbuilding, electronics, telecommunications equipment and steel making, with substantial public funding separate from the government budget for science and technology. While these industries have made substantial progress in
 acquiring technological capabilities, they have had little impact on the technology development and competitiveness of the rest of industry. 2.11 Indonesia also has been spending substantial resources to support public R&D laboratories. For the industrial sector there are three main public R&D institutions that provide technology support services. The Indonesian Institute of Sciences (LIPI) was established in 1967. Its main task is assist the President in organizing national R&D, to give guidance, services and advice to Government on national science and technology policy, improve Indonesia's scientific capability and cooperate with national and international scientific bodies. It also carries out basic research and technology development activities in the natural sciences, engineering sciences, social sciences and humanities and plays a major role in the development of the country's science and technology infrastructure, including calibration and metrology and information services in science and technology in over 19 centers for R&D and technology services. LIPI employs about 4,000 people including over 300 Ph.D. and Masters degree holders. In 1993/94 LIPI had a total operating budget, including development and recurrent expenditure, equivalent to about US$42 million, of which about 90 percent was funded by government. 2.12 The Agency for the Assessment and Application of Technology (BPPT) was established in 1978 to be in charge of the selection, assessment and application of science and technology for the development of national industry. Like LIPI, BPPT is a non- departmental government agency reporting directly to the President. Its principal tasks are to: (a) formulate technology policies and programs to promote industrial and national development; (b) ensure coordination in the implementation of programs for the assessment and application of technology; (c) provide services to government and the private sector in the application of technology; (d) carry out technology related activities in support of the government's development policies and the application of technology for industrial and national development. BPPT consists of over 21 technical directorates covering the basic and applied sciences, technology development, industrial analysis, natural resource development and systems analysis, as well as a number of technical laboratories in such fields as aero- and gas dynamics, energy resources, construction testing. It employs about 3,000 people including over 300 Ph.D. and Masters degree holders. In 1993/94 BPPT had a total operating budget, including development and recurrent expenditure, equivalent to about US$42 million, of which about 95 percent was funded by government. 2.13 There are 9 national level R&D laboratories, specialized by industrial subsector under the Ministry of Industry's Agency for Industrial Research and Development (BPPI) as well as other specialized centers, e.g., the Center for Industrial Standards (PUSTAN), and thirteen regional-level R&D institutes. Their mission is to focus on applied R&D and technology support services, including testing and calibration services, for industry. It employs about 3700 people including over 50 Ph.D. and Masters degree holders. In 1993/94 BPPI had a total operating budget, including development and recurrent
 expenditure, equivalent to about US$14 million, of which about 70 percent was funded by government. 2.14 These public technology support institutions typically are inward oriented and supply-driven, and do not have the incentives or management systems to respond effectively to the demands of private industry. As a result the degree of self-financing of Indonesia's PTSIs tends to be low compared to other countries (Table 2.1). The Government has developed an Action Plan to substantially increase the degree of self- financing of the PTSIs (para 3.13), in light of the need to commercialize their activities. At the same time, while there are some notable exceptions, overall the PTSIs generally are not at the cutting edge of science and technology, e.g., their scientific output in the form of international patents or publications in internationally refereed journals is rather limited. They also are fragmented across ministries and do little collaborative research and development. Many of the PTSIs under the State Ministry for Research and Technology often focus on supporting the strategic industries rather than the needs of the private sector. Those under the Ministry of Industry focus more on private industry and meeting the technology needs of SMIs in particular, but they are not commercially oriented and have weak links with industry.  - 8 - 2.15 While Indonesia's deregulation program has created a conducive policy and regulatory environment for technological upgrading in industry, technical support services to facilitate the adoption and absorption of imported technology by industry, particularly SMIs, are weak. Most of those services are provided by the PTSIs, where over 80 percent of the country's scarce scientific, technical and engineering manpower are employed. The private provision of those services to SMIs also are limited. There are only a few domestic technology consulting firms that are perceived by Indonesian firms to be of international quality (Annex 10). To match the other high performing countries in the region, technology extension services need to be substantially strengthened to help industrial firms adopt best practice, off-the-shelf imported technologies and improve product quality, improve productivity, reduce rejects and production costs, and increase yields. Indonesia now needs to place greater emphasis on supporting the private sector's efforts, particularly those of small and medium enterprises, to improve their industrial competitiveness through technological upgrading. The three major priorities are to: (a) reorient the technology infrastructure towards the diffusion of best-practice technologies in demand by industry through restructuring of the public R&D institutions; (b) strengthen technology extension and MSTQ services provided by the public and private sectors; and (c) improve the coordination of technology and industrial development policies and programs. These are the priorities addressed in the proposed Industrial Technology Development Project (ITDP).
 - 9 - 3. THE PROJECT A. Project Origin and Formulation 3.01 Indonesia has had three World Bank funded projects supporting technology development. The Science and Technology Training project (LN 2599-IND) provided support for overseas training of scientists and engineers which was continued under the Professional and Human Resources Development Project (LN 3134-IND). The latter project also included financing for development of an Action Plan to strengthen industrial technology development and for the design of improved management systems at the Agency for the Assessment and Application of Technology (BPPT) and the Indonesian Institute of Sciences (LIPI). Those projects helped create a core team within BPPT and LIPI that is working on a reorientation of technology policy toward the private sector and has helped prepare the basic design of the project. With support from a Japanese Grant Facility, each of the agencies were able to undertake a studv tour abroad to learn first- hand how other countries have implemented similar technology projects. Preparation of the project built on those earlier projects and took into account best practices internationally and consideration of alternative project designs, including the lessons drawn by the Bank's Operations Evaluation Department from the implementation of other Bank technology projects (Report No. 12138) and experiences with other projects in Indonesia with technology related components, e.g., the Industrial Restructuring Project (LN 3040-IND) which helped strengthen industrial metrology, testing and extension services under the Agency for Industrial R&D of the Ministry of Industrv (BPPI). Formulation of the project also benefited from the use of consultants who have designed and implemented similar projects successfully elsewhere. Based on the experience of previous projects in Indonesia, the implementation of the project is predicated on: (a) maximizing the use of existing resources and institutions; (b) having clear performance standards and incentives for the public technology support institutions to encourage them to be more responsive to the needs of industry; and (c) close coordination within GOI in the development of policies, action plans and programns to enhance industrial competitiveness through technology development. B. Project Objectives 3.02 The objective of the project is to enhance the competitiveness of Indonesian industry, particularly of small and medium industries (SNMIs), by: (a) providing public and private technology support services; (b) facilitating the access to public and private technology service providers; (c) strengthening public technology support institutions; and (d) improving the formulation and coordination of industrial technology policies.
 - 10- C. Project Components and Description 3.03 The project has four components. It would: (a) strengthen Indonesia's system of industrial metrology, standards, testing and quality (MSTQ) support services; (b) support the diffusion of good technology practices through a cost-sharing matching grant fund to finance the competitive provision of technology upgrading services to small and medium industries (SMIs) by both public and private technology suppliers; (c) provide assistance for reorienting the public research and development labs towards supporting more effective technology development in private industry, especially SMIs; and (d) strengthen the capacity to formulate and coordinate technology and industrial strategies, polices and programs. 1. Improvement of Metrology, Standards, Testing and Quality (MSTQ) Services 3.03 Effective MSTQ support services have an important role to play in enhancing industrial competitiveness since the ability to compete in global markets is directly linked to standards and product quality. However, those services are very weak in Indonesia. Dissemination of national and international standards to industry, quality awareness among firms and training in quality management practices for industry, especially SMIs, is extremely limited. Testing and calibration services are weak, e.g., only three of the twenty two laboratories under MOI are internationally accredited. The demand for support services for upgrading product quality is growing rapidly as Indonesian firms seek to attain the standards required in international markets, including ISO 9000 certification which is increasingly becoming a requirement to sell in major export markets. Using German and Japanese technical assistance Indonesia's National Standards Council (DSN) has developed a good Master Plan to strengthen MSTQ services in these areas (Annex 9). The project would support the efforts of the National Metrology Center (KIM-LIPI) and the Ministry of Industry's Center for Industrial Standards (PUSTAN) to implement their respective complimentary responsibilities under that Master Plan through technical assistance and training to improve the dissemination of standards to industry, especially SMIs; and implement programs for improved testing and calibration services and national certification of product quality and quality management practices, including ISO 9000 certification for industry. 3.04 The National Metrology Center (KIM). KIM is Indonesia's primary metrology center; it also operates a national calibration network in which there are a number of private as well as public sector calibration service providers. One of its major tasks is to calibrate the equipment of public and private sector testing laboratories throughout the country which is essential for ensuring the accuracy of their testing equipment. Firms also have the choice of sending their equipment abroad for calibration, which is an expensive option. However, KIM has yet to become recognized and accepted internationally. Technical assistance would be provided for KIM--through a twinning arrangement with a leading international metrology and calibration laboratory selected competitively using
 - 11 - Bank guidelines (para 4.06)--for building its management and institutional capacity, including improvement of the technical proficiency of KIM with the objective of gaining international recognition and accreditation, which is vital to implementation of Indonesia's ISO 9000 certification program. Performance targets for KIM were agreed during appraisal (para 4.13). 3.05 Ministry of Industry's Center for Industrial Standards (PUSTAN). PUSTAN also has an important role to play in the implementation of the national industrial standards system and ISO 9000 certification of industrial enterprises. PUSTAN would receive technical assistance under the project from an internationally reputed accredited laboratory to improve the performance and institutional capacity of five of the Ministry of Industry's testing laboratories to gain international recognition and/or accreditation. Furthermore, MOI staff in eight MOI R&D institutes would be trained as MSTQ extension agents under the project. PUSTAN also would receive technical assistance to: (a) develop in cooperation with the Indonesian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (KADIN) programs to promote quality awareness and implementation in industry; and (b) initiate ISO 9000 certification of 40 SMIs as a pilot demonstration to the rest of industry and as a learning-by-doing training program for its staff. A comprehensive training program for managers, supervisors and quality personnel of SMIs in all aspects of quality management would be instituted by PUSTAN in cooperation with several Indonesian technical universities. In addition, PUSTAN would facilitate the translation into Bahasa Indonesia and wide dissemination of eight major practical textbooks in the field of MSTQ. Performance targets for PUSTAN were agreed during appraisal (para 4. 13). 2. Diffusion of Good Technology Practices 3.07 In Indonesia demand for technical advice for improving productivity, and product quality, reliability, design and delivery times is expanding rapidly in response to increasing international competition. Large and some medium-sized firms receive such technology support services primarily through technology agreements with foreign joint- venture partners, and from domestic and international consultants. However, most small and medium sized firms do not have those contacts and often are reluctant to use such expertise due to concerns about confidentiality, value for money and their often limited ability to identify suitable experts and use them effectively. Those SMIs who do seek assistance do so primarily from public technology support services and, increasingly, private consulting firms and individual consultants (Annex 10) although the quality of domestic service providers, both public and private, is generally weak.  - 26 - 5. PROJECT JUSTIFICATION AND RISKS A. Rationale for Bank Involvement 5.01 Through past projects in the area of science and technology, the Bank has developed a close relationship with Government counterparts in the field of technology (BPPT, LIPI, MOI, BAPPENAS). In the course of project preparation, the Bank has expanded its previous focus on science and technology training to establish a dialogue with Government agencies and the private sector on the public sector role in the provision of technology services. The proposed project would allow the Bank to maintain and expand this dialogue, and ensure that it leads to results on the ground. 5.02 The 1995 Country Assistance Strategy for Indonesia emphasizes the importance of improving Indonesia's competitiveness and the need for a shift toward a productivity based economy and the complimentary private provision of supporting infrastructure services. The proposed project addresses each of these areas through its support for more effective provision of technology services to help improve the competitiveness of Indonesian industry. The package of policy reforms, institutional strengthening and capacity building supported under the project is in particular expected to make a contribution to enhancing the competitiveness of Indonesia's SMI manufacturing sector, the target group of the project. The experience gained under the project would provide a useful input into Indonesia's technology policies and programs. 5.03 In the expectation of closer Bank cooperation, GOI also has introduced, for the first time, performance measurement and measures to promote accountability in public R&D management in Indonesia. Project preparation has been an instrument for establishing consensus and coordination among these Government agencies and a dialogue with private industry, which are essential to strengthening the link between technology and industrial policies. Our involvement has helped GOI to take advantage of the lessons from Bank-supported technology projects throughout the world and prompted it to take a more pro-active stance in focusing industrial technology development policies and programs and in aligning them more clearly with private sector development and industrial competitiveness. The Bank has also played a key role in establishing a common policy and institutional framework for industrial technology development that is being supported by other financiers, including the Asian Development Bank.

Project Justification Project Rationale and Design 5.04 Over the last decade, the Indonesian Government has been engaged in a process of deregulating the economy, liberalizing the foreign investment regime, and lowering import barriers, all of which have increased competitive pressures and hence the demand for technology services. Against this background, the proposed project seeks to improve the productivity of the Government's expenditures in the technology area so as to maximize the supply-side response to the opening of the economy. 5.05 Specifically, the project addresses two important market failures in the area of technology-services. First, there is a demand-side failure. Many Indonesian SMI managers underestimate the value of and need for technology improvements, and are reluctant to spend scarce funds on new technologies. Temporary cost buy-downs on technological services, by encouraging reluctant firms to move up the learning curve and thereby inducing spillover or demonstration effects on neighboring firms, would help overcome this problem. Second, there is a supply-side failure. Even if technology demanders were perfectly informed about the value of new technology, technology services, if left to the market, would be underprovided, on account of their public good nature (the available supply of a new technology is not diminished by the adoption by a firm of that technology). 5.06 The project addresses these market failures by lowering the cost (through subsidies) of technology services, both public and private. In particular, the DAPATI scheme is a response to the first market failure: its declining schedule of subsidies for technology services is specifically designed to encourage firms to test the waters and move up the technology learning curve. 5.07 The existence of market failure in itself can only point to the consideration of govemment action; it cannot justify it. The possibility of "govemment failure"--of the govemment's involvement only making matters worse--must also be considered, especially in countries such as Indonesia, where the track-record of public sector technology institutions is mixed. The project addresses the risk of government failure, and attempts to minimize it in various ways: (i) the provision, through DAPATI, of subsidies for private as well as public providers of technology services will facilitate the development of private-sector technology suppliers, unencumbered by the bureaucratic constraints of the public sector and subject to the forces of competition;
 - 28 - (ii) improved efficiency, industry-responsiveness and commercialization of government sector institutes are explicit aims of the project. The PTSIs will be forced to become more reliant on industry for their revenue, and will be given technical assistance to enable them to do so; (iii) the heavy reliance on performance targets, and the incentives imbedded in the project to meet these, will promote better performance and also help develop a result-oriented outlook among the PTSIs; and (iv) the DAPATI program has been designed as a pilot. It will be closely monitored and thoroughly evaluated, including through the use of a sample survey, both to ensure effective use of funds and to provide a good information base on which to decide whether or not to continue with the program after project completion (see 5.1 2). In summary, the project has been designed to help overcome market failures in the key area of technology service provision, while minimizing the likelihood of government failure. Project Benefits 5.08 The benefits of the project do not lend themselves to precise quantitative analysis. However, there is ample evidence from the high performing East Asian countries and previous projects in Indonesia that effective technology support services do yield high economic and financial retums for manufacturing companies through reduced product defects, faster manufacturing turnaround times, lower inventories, higher productivity, increased domestic and export sales and new product designs. These benefits are multiples of the cost of the corresponding services and substantially increase the returns to SMIs' existing investments in plant, equipment and human capital. 5.09 Any consideration of benefits must also take into account the substantial, though again not easily quiantified, catalytic effect the project would have on ongoing public sector investments in the provision of technological services. Given its focus on improving the incentives and management practices of the participating PTSIs, the project can be expected, if successful, to have a demonstration effect which would influence overall Government technology policy and expenditures in the direction of commercialization, accountability and transparency. An alternative project design based on investing heavily in additional equipment for selected Government research institutes was considered but rejected on the grounds that it would not have this catalytic impact. Instead, planned investments in new equipment have been kept to the bare minimum required to implement the business plans of the participating PTSIs. This approach has worked well in other Bank technology projects, notably in the Industrial Technology Development Project (LN 3119-IN, CR 2064) in India.
 - 29- Fiscal Impact 5.10 The project is expected to have a positive fiscal impact since it would enable the Government to deliver the same level of technology services with a lower budget. There are two reasons for this. First, the expected net impact of the project on the private provision of technology services is positive (mainly as a result of the DAPATI program, and the stimulus to demand this will give). Second, the self-financing ratio of the PTSIs would increase as a result of the project. C. Project Risks 5.11 The reorientation of the public technology infrastructure towards commercial use and result-oriented management, the effective coordination of Government policies for industry and science and technology and the development of competent private service providers may be slower than envisaged. Similarly, the SMI sector may be slow in accessing the new services being offered. To help minimize these risks, project preparation was extended to: (a) help build consensus within Government on the need for and ways to achieve this strategic reorientation of public support for technology development, including drawing on best practices from other countries' experiences; (b) develop a new policy framework that will drive the PTSIs to commercialize their research and development and require of them greater accountability for achieving measurable results, and increased transparency and better management of the operations of the PTSIs; (c) provide the PTSIs under the project an opportunity to develop sound business plans for their commercialization based on assessments of market demands and build a pipeline of technology projects with private industry; and (d) obtain the participation of private industry and professional consulting associations in project design and implementation. 5.12 There is also a risk in relation to sustainability. As mentioned, DAPATI is a pilot scheme. There is a danger that, even if it were considered a great success, the Government, for budgetary reasons, would not continue to fund it after project completion. In this regard, the planned evaluation of DAPATI would provide the Government with a very good information base on which to decide the future of the program. The Bank would also review with the Government throughout the project implementation period the success of DAPATI, and plans, if appropriate, for its extension after the closing date for the project.

An identification mission in 1990 found that the various organizations responsible for Indonesia's industrial standards systems while understanding basic principles, did not fully appreciate the impact of MSTQ on technology transfer, exports, and competitiveness in the global economy. Like a number of other emerging industrial economies at that time, Indonesia was starting to transition from an inward focused "classical" MSTQ system to one which is more in tune with international and regional considerations. These stages of evolution are illustrated here. Today it is evident that Indonesia is emerging from that transition phase and is posed to provide requisite MSTQ services in support of industrial technology development. It is evident that both the private and public sectors recognize that quality is a critical factor in international competitiveness. There is a better appreciation of the interrelationships between metrology/calibration and quality; laboratory accreditation and product certification; quality and calibration, and laboratory accreditation; and the standards for testing, accrediting, and certifying products and service. Many Indonesian companies, however, believe that improved quality entails increased costs. Domestic markets are cost-sensitive and not quality conscious. Manufacturers do not appreciate how improving quality can reduce costs by increasing yields, reducing rejects, and improving productivity.

Quality training services are limited to occasional short courses by the Indonesian Quality Management Association, the Institute for Management Education and itinerant foreign trainers. A reputed comprehensive quality management curriculum does not exist which would enable those assigned to manage or supervise quality functions to acquire the broad range of quality training necessary for such positions. A particularly challenging handicap is the lack of textbooks in Bahasa Indonesia on quality management. Only one or two primers outlining ISO 9000 have been translated. 4. As Indonesian MSTQ institutions transition to a more strategic MSTQ system with a global outlook, efforts are underway to address the more significant impediments at the enterprise level and to upgrade institutions to provide better support to the private sector. The results of recent World Bank, German, and Japanese MSTQ assistance projects have been assimilated into well-grounded plans to implement a comprehensive, cohesive national MSTQ system during Repelita VI. This five-year MSTQ plan pragmatically addresses many needs and issues. As expected, considerable attention is focused on equipping and upgrading calibration and testing laboratories, but the need for human resource development, education, and effective management systems is also addressed. Specific tasks include accrediting testing laboratories, and establishing a credible, internationally recognized calibration network. Development of uniquely Indonesian standards is de-emphasized and resources are provided to reorient standardization committees to adopt or adapt international standards. This is in tune with the GATT/WTO accord on non-tariff trade barriers which requires nations to give precedence to international standards. 5. ISO 9000 certification is also a major priority in Indonesia's MSTQ strategy. Less than fifty Indonesian firms have been certified so far, and nearly all of those certifications took place abroad because of the absence of an internationally recognized accreditation system, and the lack of qualified assessors and consulting firms that could help firms implement ISO 9000 quality management systems. Indonesia's strategy provides for implementation of a national system for registering lead assessors, accrediting testing laboratories and improving the calibration of test equipment in Indonesia's public and private labs. 6. Within government, there are two main providers of MSTQ services to industry. The National Metrology Center (KIM) is Indonesia's primary metrology center. One of its major tasks is to calibrate the equipment of public and private sector testing laboratories throughout the country which is essential for ensuring the accuracy of their testing equipment. Under the Industrial Technology Development Project technical assistance would be provided for KIM--through a twinning arrangement with a leading international metrology and calibration laboratory selected competitively using Bank guidelines--for building its management and institutional capacity, including improvement of the technical proficiency of KIM with the objective of gaining international recognition and accreditation, which is vital to implementation of Indonesia's ISO 9000 certification program. The Ministry of Industry's Center for Industrial Standards (PUSTAN) also has an important role to play in the implementation of the national industrial standards system and ISO 9000 certification of industrial enterprises. Under the project, PUSTAN would receive technical assistance to promote industry awareness of quality management practices, including ISO 9000, and would initiate ISO 9000 certification of 40 SMIs as a pilot program.
 - 71 - ANNEX 9 Page 3 of 3 7. In addition to government providers of MSTQ services there is a small but growing number of private sector providers in Indonesia. As part of its MSTQ strategy GOI plans to improve the participation of the private sector in the provision of all MSTQ support services, including ISO 90000 assessor and consulting services, and to have substantial private sector representation in the country's main MSTQ policy making bodies and accreditation councils. The strategy calls for active involvement of the private sector and competition between public and private service providers in the provision of MSTQ services. 8. Taking advantage of the present climate and building on previous technical assistance projects, the MSTQ component of the ITDP will expedite action in priority areas identified in the Repelita VI Five- Year Plan. Institutional upgrading will concentrate on improving managerial skills. Only a limited amount of equipment will be procured, and that will be only where voids exist which would hinder laboratory accreditation. 9. The majority of the investment will be for private sector quality awareness and training with special emphasis on small and medium enterprises. Outreach to SMIs will be accomplished through extension agents working from eight MOI R&D centers. To foster quality awareness and commitment by top management, the experiences of a major private sector organization such as India's Confederation of Engineering Industries, or the Singapore Manufacturers Association will be transferred to the Indonesian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. A comprehensive quality implementation program will be initiated that will serve as a model for other sectors. Rather than build a quality training arm within the Ministry of Industry, PUSTAN will team with regional technical universities to provide a comprehensive range of quality courses under license from a world-class training provider. The courses will be tailored to the specific needs of Indonesian industry. 10. The pragmatic initiatives of the MSTQ component will enable Indonesia to put into a place time- critical institutional capabilities--a national calibration system, and a cadre of accredited testing laboratories--and will encourage the private provision of MSTQ support services which are required for the successful implementation of its Repelita VI Five-Year MSTQ plan. Introduction Developing a vibrant and sustainable market for technology services in Indonesia is the primary objective of the Technology Services Matching Grant Scheme. To determine the potential for growth in the domestic technology services market, this section first describes the current level of demand for different types of technology services in Indonesia and explains which service providers are now supplying that expertise. Then the Bank's considerable international experience in the provision of technology services through cost sharing schemes is reviewed and key success factors in the design of these programs are highlighted. Lastly, these experiences are used to design 'the matching grant scheme for providing technology services to small and medium-sized industries (SMIs) in Indonesia. The market mechanism embodied in the matching grant scheme would allow firms to determine the future growth and direction of the market for technology services in Indonesia. II. Technology Services Market in Indonesia Demand Presently, demand for technology services among small and medium-sized firms in Indonesia is weak as is the capacity of the domestic consulting industry to supply those services. Firms are reluctant to use technology service providers because of concerns about value for money, confidentiality, and their ability to identify a suitable expert and use them effectively. Demand for technology support services in Indonesia is concentrated in large and some medium-sized firms. For many medium and large firms, this demand is supplied primarily through contractual technology agreements with foreign joint- venture partners, licensing arrangements, domestic and international consulting engagements, and international contacts. Indonesian SMIs seek technical support primarily from university institutes, government laboratories, and their equipment vendors. The services SMIs most often request are process and product technology, calibration and testing, and new equipment integration. Recently, there has been growing interest among firms to undertake training in IS09000 quality systems, however, the cost is seen as prohibitive and only a few Indonesian firms have yet received certification. The TSGs' (Technology Services Groups) experience under the Industrial Restructuring Project (LN 3040-IND) has shown that there is a growing awareness among Indonesian small and medium-sized firms of the benefits of technology management services (production planning and control) and a corresponding increase in their demand for these services. Indonesia's strength in technical support services is in design engineering of metals based manufacturing. This expertise is centered in Bandung where institutes, universities and private consulting services specialize in design engineering. For example, the Polytechnic Mechanical and the Academy of Machine and Industrial Technology (ATMI) are located in Bandung, and international and domestic consultants have concentrated their engineering design offices in this area. Tlhe domestic private consulting industry has significant weaknesses. In general, consulting firms lack conceptual planning and management skills. Their management skills need to be developed at three levels: (i) the managers of consulting firms need training in internal management processes and practices; (ii) individual consultants need training in management of consulting engagements; and (iii) individual consultants need training in business management skills and quality management which could be developed into a service to be offered to client firms. In addition, local consultants report that joint engagements with international consulting firms to serve small and medium-sized industry have been unsuccessful in transferring technical skills to the local consultants. The discrepancy between the skill level of domestic and international firms is such that absorptive capacity is minimal. The cost of technology service providers varies. Consulting firms' rates are relatively transparent since client firms are aware of the BAPPENAS posted rates for consulting services. Firms use these rates to bargain contracts with consultants. As an example, a local consultant with ten years of consulting experience could be employed for up to Rp. 7.5 million per month (US$ 3,500); a comparable expatriate consultant could earn US$ 17,500 per month in fees and expenses. Government laboratories and institutes which undertake calibration and testing are unaware of how to price their services with the result that services are often provided below cost. Experience with the TSGs shows that short duration periodic consultancies are affordable for and provide benefits to SMIs. Past World Bank Experience with Cost Sharing Schemes The matching grant scheme component proposed in this project is the latest in an evolving series of cost sharing schemes which subsidize part of the cost of providing technical and management advise to private sector firms. The fundamental tenet of these programs is that they are demand-led, relying on the entrepreneur to define its needs (within the scope of the Program) and choose the service provider which is best able to solve their technology problems. These initiatives evolved during the mid- 1980's, replacing the previous models of creating or subsidizing public sector agencies to provide technology services to small- and medium-sized industries which, except for rare occasions, have proven to be ineffective. Cost sharing programs have had a substantial impact on the competitiveness of beneficiary firms. For example, under the Mauritius project (Ln. 3736-MAS) econormic benefits of 2 to I are expected. To date, eleven World Bank projects in South Asia, East Asia (including two in Indonesia), Latin America and Africa have undertaken cost sharing schemes to enhance the quality and productivity of domestic firms3. Originally, most of the cost sharing schemes were directed at exporting firms as part of export development projects, and provided subsidies for productivity improvements, sales marketing, and match making services, etc.. Increasingly, however, the focus is on productivity enhancement of technology-based firms as part of a program to diffuse technology improvements to the firm-level, regardless of whether the firm markets to the domestic or export markets. These programs have steadily been upgraded to incorporate the lessons from earlier projects. Key program success factors can be generalized across all of these projects. a. Recipient firms must have entrepreneurial drive, and government must take a hands off approach. Firms want to drive the process. Direct government intervention would be viewed by firms as business as usual. Successful programs leave it to the entrepreneurs to define their needs, instead of offering a predetermined range of expertise. b. Firms must undertake a large share of the financial burden and take responsibility for managing the consulting engagement. When firms contribute only a small share of the total cost of the consultancy, the work is taken less seriously and management responsibilities fall upon the cost sharing scheme. 3 For a more detailed review of cost sharing schemes in Bank Projects, see Staff Appraisal Report, Republic of Mauritius, Technical Assistance to Enhance Competitiveness Project (LN 3736-MAS), Annex 8.

The growth and sustainability of the market for technology services requires recipient and non-recipient firms to be willing to pay full price for consulting services by the end of the project. This can only be accomplished by phasing out the subsidy element over time and heavily marketing the resultant benefits to non-recipient firms and industrial organizations during and at the completion of the project. d. Early emphasis on program marketing and pipeline development is crucial to attracting firms to the program and achieving targeted grant disbursement levels. e. Administrative/approval procedures must be efficient and transparent. Responsiveness to firms' needs is key to attracting and developing firms' long-term interest in using technology service providers. In particular, the payment procedures to reimburse firms or pay the matching grant portion to service providers, who generally don't have excess cashflow, must be quick and non- bureaucratic. 1V. Tailoring the Matching Grant Scheme The design of the matching grant scheme is intended to generate successful consultancy projects which demonstrate to non-recipient Indonesian SMIs the economic benefits of using technology service providers, thereby developing a sustainable demand for technology services. Once the demand is created and firms are willing to pay for the services, international experience has shown that both the quality and quantity of service providers will develop to meet the demand. To develop the market for technology services in Indonesia lessons learned from previous World Bank experience have been incorporated and tailored to the realities of the Indonesian business environment. Specifically, the matching grant scheme was designed with the following elements: a. A private sector management contractor (MC) would have full responsibility for the day-to-day management of the matching grant scheme. The principal functions of the management contractor would be the promotion and marketing of the scheme, the administration and disbursement of matching grants, and assistance to Indonesian SMIs in sourcing and use of technology expertise. Government's intervention occurs at the policy level of the matching grant scheme in designing acceptance criteria, approval of projects over $50,000, and evaluation of MC performance. Direct government contact with SMIs is as a public sector technology service provider competing for firms' appointment as consultant. The benefits of using an autonomous management contractor to facilitate the scheme are that: neither private nor public sector service providers would be favored during the consultant selection process, no permanent institution is created that requires government budgetary funding after project implementation is completed, and the MC experience as a consultant is beneficial to training service providers and interacting with private sector firms.

This is far higher than under previous projects in Indonesia. Under the Industrial Restructuring Project (Loan 3040-rND) ) firms' maximum contribution was 10% of consultancy costs, and under the Second Export Development Project (Loan 2979-IND) firms' contributed only 25% towards the costs of the initial consultancy. c. Marketing efforts to build an initial pipeline are the priority of the management contractor during the initial project stages, and prior to hiring the MC, the Technical Supervisory Committee would undertake this role, including marketing the scheme to industry associations which could identify group consultancies that would benefit their member firms. d.  - 82 - ANNEX 11 Page 4 of 33 CHAPTER 1: DAPATI OVERVIEW, OBJECTIVES AND RATIONALE OVERVIEW 1.1 The Technology Services Matching Grant Scheme forms a key component of the Industrial Technology Development (ITD) Project, which is intended to facilitate the development, dissemination and adoption of improved technologies by small and medium scale industries in Indonesia. The Bahasa Indonesia name for the program is Dana Kemitraan Peningkatan Teknologi Industri, and will be referred to by its acronym DAPATI in this manual. Other related components include measures to increase the quantity, quality and market orientation of R&D and technology services provided by Government research institutes, and strengthening the system of industrial metrology, standards, testing and quality assurance services. 1.2 The purpose of the DAPATI program is to provide direct financial support to small and medium scale firms (SMIs) to upgrade their use of technology and as necessary to introduce related management improvements. The central tenet of the Program is that it is demand led. Firms are given support, principally in the form of a cost sharing grant, to obtain technology and business services from specialist suppliers. These suppliers may be private consultants (local or international, individual or part of a firm) or publicly sponsored technology services. The firm is allowed to choose the service it requires (within the scope of the Program) and the supplier. In addition to a cost sharing grant, support provided to the firm, if requested, includes assistance to identify priority problems and opportunities which could benefit from obtaining external expertise, help to make best use of the consultancy services (for example, preparation of detailed terms of reference for the consultancy, including specification of costs and required output), and help to identify suitable consultants. 1.3 DAPATI also provides support to improve the quality of consultancy available in Indonesia, and to ensure firms receive assistance under the Program only from properly qualified consultants, in two main ways: * the DAPATI Management Contractor will provide a short training course on consulting skills for all consultants wanting to operate under the program, plus related registration of specialist consultants * groups of service providers (consultants) may use DAPATI funds on a 50/50 cost sharing basis, to conduct seminars on manufacturing technology and technology management topics.
 - 83 - ANNEX 11 Page 5 of 33 1.4 The types of consultancy which can be assisted by the Program cover improvements in: * product or process technologies, quality and reliability; * productivity; * safety and environmental impact; and * management control of technical operations. A full list of qualifying activities is provided in paragraph 4.4. 1.5 DAPATI provides assistance for consultancy support only. It does not cover the cost of acquiring plant and equipment, even if this is directly related to the consultancy. OBJECTIVES AND EXPECTED RESULTS 1.6 The primary objectives of DAPATI are to: - enhance the international competitiveness of SMIs in Indonesia * improve the access of SMIs to know how in the development and use of more advanced technologies * improve firm level productivity, product quality, design and response times * encourage SMIs to grow into higher value added and export oriented production * to improve the capabilities of SMIs to act as suppliers to large firms in Indonesia. 1.7 In support of these primary objectives there are three secondary objectives specific to the services available through DAPATI:
 - 84 - ANNEX 1 1 Page 6 of 33 * to encourage SMIs to use extemal expertise where appropriate to help overcome constraints to competitiveness * to improve linkages between firms and publicly and privately sponsored technology services * to increase the quantity and quality of technical and related management consultancy services available in Indonesia. 1.8 DAPATI will address these objectives by providing cost sharing grants to SMIs to help them obtain technology services, and by providing training for the service providers. Expected results include: * improvements in SMIs' productivity and product quality and reliability, and consequent increases in revenues and profitability. * a substantial increase in the number and quality of technology support services available to and affordable by SMIs in Indonesia. i a greater willingness of SMIs to use consulting services in future at full market costs. The increase in both demand and supply beyond the period of the program therefore secures long term benefits in the availability and use of support services. RATIONALE 1.9 The rationale for DAPATI is as follows. SMIs frequently need assistance from experts outside the firm to upgrade their use of technology and to achieve substantial benefits from this process. However, most SMIs are also reluctant to use outsiders for a variety of reasons, including concems about confidentiality, value for money, and their ability to identify a suitable expert and to use them effectively. 1.10 A cost sharing grant can significantly reduce this initial barrier to using technology services. Exposure to these services, properly conceived and delivered, increases SMIs willingness and ability to use them in future.
 - 85 - ANNEX I 1 Page 7 of33 1.11 Public and private sector technology services often compete for the same SMI market. The purpose of DAPATI is not to favor one sector or the other, but to give firms a choice of which provider to use. Training for consultants, an integral part of DAPATI, will also be equally available to public and private sector service providers. 1.12 Previous work by the Bank and others in Indonesia confirms that the above rationale is applicable here. Most SMIs are not inclined to use outside specialists, but frequently they need assistance to improve productivity and product quality, and better use of existing plant and equipment. 1.13 However, the consultancy sector is poorly developed in Indonesia. Private sector consultants serve mainly large firms, and few have all the skills and experience appropriate for SMIs. In the public sector, the technology service organizations are not demand driven, nor in most cases are they used to providing consultancy services on commercial terms. Nevertheless, experience of the Technical Service Groups, supported by a previous World Bank loan, indicates that there is demand for technical services among SMIs provided the right approach is taken and quality services are available. The Export Support Board Matching Grant Program also demonstrates the usefulness of cost sharing grants to stimulate demand for services.

 - 112- ANNEX 12 Pa2e 1 of 6 ACTION PLAN Industrial Technology Development Proiect Commercialization of Public Technology Support Institutions 1. In order to help private industry in Indonesia improve its international competitiveness, Government is committed to improving the delivery of public technology support services to industrial firms, i.e., research and development, improvement of productivity, efficiency, and innovation, and testing and quality upgrading services. This would be done by moving Indonesia's Public Technology Support Institutions (PTSIs) closer to meeting the needs of private industry, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises. Ultimately, the Government intends to develop them into independent legal entities, but still in the frame work of their mission as agent of technology development. 2. To realize these objectives, the Government intends to implement the following actions: - give the PTSIs necessary incentives to become more demand driven and commercially oriented and establish targets for them to become increasingly self-financing; - reduce Government controls to encourage the institutions to become more agile in responding to the technological needs of industrial firms, while also increasing the institutions' accountability for results; - implement internal management reforms at the institutions to ensure that they become more professionally managed and results oriented; - encourage private provision of technology support services and competition between, and among, public and private technology services providers; and - encourage provision of technology support services and incentives to private industries. 3. A number of initiatives have been taken in recent years to improve the incentives for PTSIs, even though further initiatives are necessary for PTSIs to become more commercial. BPPT has recently implemented a new income- sharing scheme that allows its working units and laboratories to share earning from industry. The charter of LIPI noW also provide for similar income-sharing schemes and permits its working units and laboratories to accumulate industrial earnings from
 - 113 - ANNEX 12 Pa2e 2 of 6 one year to the next to build cash reserves for improvement of their facilities and equipment. The MOI institutes have been permitted since 1990 to apply revenues from industrial sources to cover some of the operating costs of the institutes. 4. This letter further elaborates on the measures which the Government intends to undertake to implement the above actions. 5. Increased self-financin2. One of the key measures for commercializing the PTSIs will be to promote and increase their funding from industrial sources and gradually phase out their financial support from the Government budget. In this regard, income generation targets have been established for all PTSIs at BPPT, LIPI, and MOI. 6. At BPPT the share of earning from non-governmental sources through the sale of technology and technology services in total BPPT expenditure is targeted to increase from less than 5 percent today to 25 percent by the year 2000. LIPI's self-financing ratio is expected to rise from 15 percent today to 75 percent by the year 2000. Likew,se for the MOI R&D Institutes such self-financing targets have been established. For example, the R&D Institute for the Chemicals Industry (BBIK) and the Semarang Industrial Institute (BISm) are expected to increase their self- financing ratios from 18 percent and 48 percent, respectively in 1994, to 48 percent and 75 percent respectively by the year 2000 (see attachment). 7. Improvement Incentives and Flexibility in Earning Usaze. It is recognized that incentives for management and staff of PTSIs need to be improved to provide greater stimulus for commercialization of their operations. The main measures to be pursued would be to permit the institutes to a. retain earnings from industrial contracts b. use those earning flexibly, including for incentives for researchers and staff of PTSIs, for covering expenses to develop business and deliver services to industry, and for building cash reserves to improve the facilities and equipment of the institutes. c. accumulate balance from one fiscal year to the next for securing sustainability of technology support services to industry. 8. Reformin! Internal Management. In addition, it is necessary to implement improvements in the internal management of PTSIs. - First, the MOI institutes will establish advisory boards--including representation from the private sector and user industry associations--which will meet periodically to review the work of the PTSIs, and advise them on the ways
 - 114 - ANNEX 12 Paye 3 of 6 and means to strengthen the links between the institutes and private industry. At MOI institutes, further organizational restructuring will be undertaken to bring their research groups and development groups together. - Second, all MOI institutes are required to prepare business plans that should be targeted to meet the needs of industry. Those plans would become the main instruments for monitoring the operations of the institutes against annual performance targets. The plans would identify the major market for the institutes' technology services, the competitive advantage of the institutes, their expectations on penetration of those markets, and their related investment requirements in hardware and human resource development. The plans would need to clearly support the orientation of institutes toward activities which would realize increasing self-financing of their activities. In addition, this model approach is expected to be implemented by other PTSIs regarding their missions. - Third, BPPT, LIPI, and two of MOI's institutes. BBIK and the BISm--will implement modern business development and technology management practices and related management information system to: a. establish key functions that are critical to generating revenue through commercial research and technology licensing, including technology marketing, business development, and contract and intellectual property management; b strengthen internal management system to support contract research, including modern budgeting, costing, and technology pricing systems, project management, and human resources management systems, and c. provide management and staff training to facilitate the transition to industry-oriented technology service organizations. - Fourth, to help BPPT, LIPI and the MOI institutes design and implement these improvements in their internal management system, the Government will seek technical assistance through collaboration with foreign organization which have a demonstrated capability to manage successful contract research organizations. The local institutes will engage in long-term partnership (twinning arrangements) with such qualified foreign organizations. To synergize the strengths of various Indonesian PTSIs, twinning among PTSIs belonging to different agencies also will be undertaken. As a pilot, P3KT (LIPI) and BBIK (MOI) will seek greater cooperation to provide more effective technology services to the Indonesian chemical industry.
 - 115 - ANNEX 12 Pate 4 of 6 9. Encouraging Comnetitive Provision of Technolo2y Support Services. The government will strongly encourage competitive provision of technology support services between public and private technology service providers. Already there is substantial competition in the provision Qf services to industry for improving product quality, reliability and delivery, and for improving product designs and productivity, and the Government will seek to further facilitate entry of new qualified private service providers. This will be further encouraged through the matching grant scheme of the proposed Technology Services Matching Grant Scheme. As part of the arrangements for implementing the DAPATI, the training would be available to registered consultants for improving their planning, management and delivery of consulting services. Also, the Government will seek to provide for a more equitable competition environment among private and public technology service providers by adjusting the fees of PTSIs charged to their clients to reflect the true cost of services and to avoid cross-subsidies between PTSIs and public enterprises. 10. To provide support for the implementation of the above action plan for commercializing the operations of the PTSIs, the Government seeks support from the World Bank in the preparation and implementation of an Industrial Technology Development Project (ITDP). On the basis of the above actions and the support provided under the project, the Government of Indonesia aims to considerably strengthen the contribution of the PTSIs and private providers of technology support services toward improved competitiveness of industry. 11. In addition, BAPPENAS, Ministry of Finance, State Minister for Technological Research, and other related Government Agencies will provide necessary legal aspects for the implementation of this action plan.

doc.abstracts: The objective of the Industrial Technology Development Project is to enhance the competitiveness of Indonesian industry, particularly of small and medium industries (SMIs), by: 1) providing public and private technology support services; 2) facilitating the access to public and private technology service providers; 3) strengthening public technology support institutions; and 4) improving the formulation and coordination of industrial technology policies. The project has four components: 1) improvement of metrology, standards, testing and quality (MSTQ) support services; 2) diffusion of good technology practices through a cost-sharing matching grant fund to finance the competitive provision of technology upgrading services to SMIs by both public and private technology suppliers; 3) improvement of the productivity of public research and development (R&D); and 4) improvement of industrial and technology policy formulation.
